conclusion: The suitcase has a total mass of 15 kg and is pulled with an oblique upward force to achieve uniform motion on a horizontal surface. The gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s², sin 37° = 0.6, and the resistance force is proportional to the supporting force of the ground with a ratio μ.
The image shows a suitcase with wheels and a handle, which can be pushed or pulled on the ground.
The goal is to find the values of μ (the ratio of resistance force to supporting force) and θ (the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction).
The suitcase is rectangular in shape and has a ridged surface.

premise: The forces acting on the suitcase include gravity (G), the supporting force of the ground (N), and the resistance force (F).
conclusion: The force of gravity acts downward, the supporting force of the ground acts upward, and the resistance force acts horizontally opposing motion.

premise: The suitcase is in uniform motion on a horizontal surface.
conclusion: The net force acting on the suitcase is zero in both horizontal and vertical directions.

premise: The horizontal forces include the horizontal component of the pulling force (Fcosθ) and the resistance force (f).
conclusion: The horizontal equilibrium condition is Fcosθ = f.

premise: The vertical forces include the vertical component of the pulling force (Fsinθ), the supporting force of the ground (N), and the gravitational force (G).
conclusion: The vertical equilibrium condition is N + Fsinθ = G.

premise: The resistance force (f) is proportional to the supporting force of the ground (N), with a ratio μ.
Substitute f = μN into the horizontal equilibrium condition Fcosθ = f.
Substitute N = G - Fsinθ (from the vertical equilibrium condition) into Fcosθ = μN.
Rearrange the equation Fcosθ = μ(G - Fsinθ).
The minimum value of the pulling force is given as F = 90 N.
